studies.title: The Experience of Landscape
studies.finding: Foundational theory that humans prefer environments offering both prospect (open views for surveillance) and refuge (enclosed spaces for safety), based on evolutionary psychology

studies.title: Humans, Habitats and Aesthetics (Chapter in The Biophilia Hypothesis)
studies.finding: Extended Appleton's theory with empirical research showing preference for savanna-like environments with scattered trees providing both open views and shelter

studies.title: Building for Life: Designing and Understanding the Human-Nature Connection
studies.finding: Established biophilic design framework incorporating prospect-refuge as core principle; published by Island Press

examples.description: Frank Lloyd Wright's 1939 design exemplifies prospect-refuge: cantilevered terraces provide open views over waterfall (prospect) while stone walls and low ceilings create intimate protected spaces (refuge)
examples.source: Widely documented in architectural literature - specific outcome data would need verification

examples.description: 2018 biophilic workplace design explicitly incorporates prospect-refuge principles with varied ceiling heights, alcoves, and overlook spaces
examples.source: NBBJ Architects design documentation - specific employee wellness outcomes would need verification

notes: Prospect-refuge theory has strong theoretical foundations (Appleton 1975 is well-established). However, without web search access, I cannot verify current statistics, recent studies, or specific program outcomes. The academic foundation is solid, but quantified built-environment outcomes need verification. Core studies are from 1970s-2000s; recent empirical validation in architecture would strengthen this pattern. Recommend web search to find: (1) recent VR/eye-tracking studies on prospect-refuge preferences, (2) post-occupancy evaluations from biophilic buildings, (3) current WELL/LEED project data.
